awd_titl_txt: CompCog: Helping people make more future-minded decisions using optimal gamification
awd_abstract_narration:
Helping people, teams, and organizations achieve important goals may be one of the most effective ways to increase productivity and promote human progress. To achieve their goals, many organizations employ financial incentives or game elements, such as points, levels, and badges, to motivate employees to become more productive. This project develops a theoretical foundation and computational tools for designing better incentive structures to help people achieve their goals. The project connects the crucial challenges of goal achievement studied in psychology to the computational methods from artificial intelligence that can be used to solve them. By bridging this gap the project provides a new way for artificial intelligence to communicate with people and empowers them to overcome the motivational obstacles and cognitive limitations that might otherwise prevent them from making good decisions. 

At the heart of this project is a mathematical theory for optimizing incentive structures to help people make better decisions in complex, partially unknown environments. This theory is used as the basis for two cognitive prostheses that leverage artificial intelligence and gamification to help people achieve their goals: an intelligent to-do list gamification system that helps people become more productive and procrastinate less and an app that reinforces good habits. Field experiments are used to evaluate whether these cognitive prostheses are effective in the real world, working towards the development of intelligent systems that can aid people in setting and achieving their goals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to develop and evaluate a mathematical framework for designing optimal incentive structures that help people make more far-sighted decisions. The research comprised three parts: The first part aimed to extend optimal gamification to support decision-making in situations that require information gathering and exploration and ii) teach people to make better decisions by presenting optimal pseudo-rewards as feedback. The second part aimed to develop cognitive prostheses that leverage optimal gamification to help people improve their behavior. This included a cognitive prosthesis that helps people overcome motivational obstacles to goal pursuit through to-do list gamification and a cognitive prosthesis that helps people develop better habits. The third part aimed to apply optimal gamification to support goal-setting. This involved devising algorithms for scoring and recommending sub-goals, and creating and evaluating an app that supports people in goal-setting.

 The project was successful in achieving these goals. We extended and corroborated our finding that practicing decision-making with a cognitive tutor that provides optimal metacognitive feedback on individual decision operations is more effective improving human decision-making than conventional approaches, showing that the benefits of training with our cognitive tutor transferred to a more challenging task, naturalistic task. Moreover, we showed that our general approach can be successfully applied wide range of decision problems; for each decision problem it was applied to, it automatically discovered and successfully taught the resource-rational decision strategy for that specific decision problem. We found that students’ learning behavior and learning outcomes in digital learning environments can be significantly improved by incentivizing each learning activity by a number of points that reflect how much the student will learn from that activity. We found that optimal gamification can help people overcome motivational obstacles to enacting desired health behaviors, suggesting that optimal gamification could be a promising theoretical framework for supporting behavior change. We found that the ways in which people misestimate the duration of their tasks and misjudge the value of achieving their goals causes the goal suggestions derived through optimal gamification to be net harmful. We found that the subgoals derived from resource-rational models of goal pursuit can help people to efficiently solve complex problems in a simulated management task. We also developed a theoretical framework for identifying the strategies people use and supporting better decisions through the construction of “optimal nudges” that modify decision environments to best support better decisions.

This grant partially supported or enabled the scientific training and professional development of two Masters students, four PhD students, and one postdoc. It enabled many of these students to publish their first conference or journal articles. It also helped three PhD students and one postdoc to gain experience in supervising students and project management. In addition to the scientific training in cognitive science, psychology, and computer science, the project also provided practical training in user-experience design and usability engineering. In addition, our method for incentivizing learning activities was incorporated into the digital education platform Dawn of Civilization that, in 2022 alone, delivered 8.5 million mini-lessons to more than 350,000 disadvantaged youth in more than 45 countries in Africa, South-East Asia, and South America.
